articles.headline: They Relied on Chinese Vaccines. Now They’re Battling Outbreaks.
articles.snippet: More than 90 countries are using Covid shots from China. Experts say recent infections in those places should serve as a cautionary tale in the global effort to fight the disease.
articles.abstract: More than 90 countries are using Covid shots from China. Experts say recent infections in those places should serve as a cautionary tale in the global effort to fight the disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mongolia promised its people a “Covid-free summer.” Bahrain said there would be a “return to normal life.” The tiny island nation of the Seychelles aimed to jump-start its economy.

articles.headline: Saudi Operatives Who Killed Khashoggi Received Paramilitary Training in U.S.
articles.snippet: The training, approved by the State Department, underscores the perils of military partnerships with repressive governments.
articles.abstract: The training, approved by the State Department, underscores the perils of military partnerships with repressive governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four Saudis who participated in the 2018 killing of the Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi received paramilitary training in the United States the previous year under a contract approved by the State Department, according to documents and people familiar with the arrangement.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Julian E. Barnes and Michael LaForgia

articles.headline: Tech Giants, Fearful of Proposals to Curb Them, Blitz Washington With Lobbying
articles.snippet: Executives, lobbyists, and more than a dozen groups paid by Big Tech have tried to head off bipartisan support for six bills meant to undo the dominance of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.
articles.abstract: Executives, lobbyists, and more than a dozen groups paid by Big Tech have tried to head off bipartisan support for six bills meant to undo the dominance of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the days after lawmakers introduced legislation that could break the dominance of tech companies, Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, called Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other members of Congress to deliver a warning.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang, David McCabe and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: With Mass Vaccination Sites Winding Down, It’s All About the ‘Ground Game’
articles.snippet: The shift away from high-volume centers is an acknowledgment of the harder road ahead: a highly targeted push, akin to get-out-the-vote efforts, to persuade the reluctant to get shots.
articles.abstract: The shift away from high-volume centers is an acknowledgment of the harder road ahead: a highly targeted push, akin to get-out-the-vote efforts, to persuade the reluctant to get shots.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWARK — There were only six tiny vials of coronavirus vaccine in the refrigerator, one Air Force nurse on duty and a trickle of patients on Saturday morning at a federally run mass vaccination site here. A day before its doors shut for good, this once-frenetic operation was oddly quiet.

articles.headline: Republicans Block Voting Rights Bill, Dealing Blow to Biden and Democrats
articles.snippet: All 50 G.O.P. senators opposed the sweeping elections overhaul, leaving a long-shot bid to eliminate the filibuster as Democrats’ best remaining hope to enact legal changes.
articles.abstract: All 50 G.O.P. senators opposed the sweeping elections overhaul, leaving a long-shot bid to eliminate the filibuster as Democrats’ best remaining hope to enact legal changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans on Tuesday blocked the most ambitious voting rights legislation to come before Congress in a generation, dealing a blow to Democrats’ attempts to counter a wave of state-level ballot restrictions and supercharging a campaign to end the legislative filibuster.

articles.headline: ‘We Are Very Free’: How China Spreads Its Propaganda Version of Life in Xinjiang
articles.snippet: Thousands of videos posted look like unfiltered glimpses of life for Uyghurs, but taken together, the videos begin to reveal clues of a broader influence campaign orchestrated by the Chinese government.
articles.abstract: Thousands of videos posted look like unfiltered glimpses of life for Uyghurs, but taken together, the videos begin to reveal clues of a broader influence campaign orchestrated by the Chinese government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands of videos posted look like unfiltered glimpses of life for Uyghurs, but taken together, the videos begin to reveal clues of a broader influence campaign orchestrated by the Chinese government.
articles.byline: By Jeff Kao, Raymond Zhong, Paul Mozur, Aliza Aufrichtig, Nailah Morgan and Aaron Krolik

articles.headline: Your Steak Is More Expensive, but Cattle Ranchers Are Missing Out
articles.snippet: Demand for beef is spiking as people dine out and grill, but the profits aren’t being evenly distributed. Ranchers blame the big meatpacking companies.
articles.abstract: Demand for beef is spiking as people dine out and grill, but the profits aren’t being evenly distributed. Ranchers blame the big meatpacking companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: At Harris’ in San Francisco — a quintessential American steakhouse with dark wood, cozy leather booths and dry martinis — the price of the popular eight-ounce filet mignon with two sides recently increased $2 to $56.

articles.headline: ‘Forbidden Fruit’: Apple Daily, Pro-Democracy Newspaper in Hong Kong, Is Forced to Close
articles.snippet: The police also arrested an editorial writer as part of an expanding national security investigation into the newspaper that has raised concerns about free speech.
articles.abstract: The police also arrested an editorial writer as part of an expanding national security investigation into the newspaper that has raised concerns about free speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Apple Daily, a popular newspaper in Hong Kong, has long needled Beijing with its rambunctious support of pro-democracy protesters, aggressive investigations of officials and lampooning of China’s Communist Party leadership. Now China has effectively silenced the paper — and along with it, one of its most defiant critics.
articles.byline: By Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May

articles.headline: Biden and Senators Close In on Bipartisan Infrastructure Deal
articles.snippet: Lawmakers were set to take a tentative framework to the White House on Thursday. Administration officials signaled the president was prepared to support it, pending final details.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers were set to take a tentative framework to the White House on Thursday. Administration officials signaled the president was prepared to support it, pending final details.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House negotiators and a group of senators reached a tentative agreement Wednesday evening on the contours of what would be a bipartisan infrastructure agreement, with lawmakers set to brief President Biden on Thursday as details were filled in.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: No End to Whiplash in Meme Stocks, Crypto and More
articles.snippet: With the pandemic starting to ease in the United States, many had expected a year of wild investments to slow. It hasn’t. Yet.
articles.abstract: With the pandemic starting to ease in the United States, many had expected a year of wild investments to slow. It hasn’t. Yet.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — All year, amateur investors, propelled by a social media frenzy and a bit of boredom, have poured money into risky forms of investments like meme stocks, SPACs and Bitcoin.

articles.headline: Warren Buffett’s Exit From the Gates Foundation Clouds Its Future
articles.snippet: Mr. Buffett, a longtime friend of Bill Gates, stepped down as a trustee of the organization just weeks after its founders announced their divorce.
articles.abstract: Mr. Buffett, a longtime friend of Bill Gates, stepped down as a trustee of the organization just weeks after its founders announced their divorce.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett, the chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, said on Wednesday that he had resigned as a trustee of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, coming just weeks after the couple announced their divorce and raising new questions about the future of the foundation.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: Yellen Steers the Economy With Brooklyn on Her Mind
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary’s economic philosophy was shaped by her youth in Bay Ridge.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary’s economic philosophy was shaped by her youth in Bay Ridge.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen thinks about restoring the millions of jobs lost to the pandemic and making the economy more equitable, her mind sometimes turns to a place that shaped her views: Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Rules for Cheerleader Punished for Vulgar Snapchat Message
articles.snippet: The decision set new limits on disciplining students for off-campus speech but did not totally bar administrators from doing so.
articles.abstract: The decision set new limits on disciplining students for off-campus speech but did not totally bar administrators from doing so.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that a Pennsylvania school district had violated the First Amendment by punishing a student for a vulgar social media message sent while she was not on school grounds.
